I alone bear the responsibility for scuttling the pocket-battleship Admiral Graf Spee. I am happy to pay with my life for any possible reflection on the honour of the flag. I shall face my fate with firm faith in the cause and the future of the nation and of my Fuehrer.</em>\"&nbsp;<span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp;</span></span></span><br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;,&quot;serif&quot;; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\"></span><span style=\"color: black;\">He then lay on Admiral Graf Spee's battle ensign and shot himself through the head.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; </span>dead body and that of the dead German sailors.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: black;\"><br />\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;Arial&quot;,&quot;sans-serif&quot;; font-size: 10.5pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Me let the world disparage and despise -- <br />\nAs one unfettered with its gilded chains, <br />\nAs one untempted by its sordid gains, <br />\nIts pleasant vice, its profitable lies; <br />\nLet Justice, blind and halt and maimed, chastise <br />\nThe rebel spirit surging in my veins, <br />\nLet the law deal me penalties and pains <br />\nAnd make me hideous in my neighbours' eyes. <br />\n<br />\nBut let me fall not in mine own esteem, <br />\nBy poor deceit or selfish greed debased. <br />\nLet me be clean from secret stain and shame, <br />\nKnow myself true, though false as hell I seem -- <br />\nKnow myself worthy, howsoe'er disgraced -- <br />\nKnow myself right, though every tongue should blame.</i></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;,&quot;serif&quot;; margin: 0in 0in 10pt;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\"><br />\n</span><span style=\"color: black;\"> </span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\"><span style=\"color: #333333; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;,&quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"> </span><span lang=\"EN\" style=\"mso-ansi-language: EN;\">On 21 August 1939, <i>Admiral Graf Spee</i> left Wilhelmshaven port with orders to raid enemy commercial shipping in the South Atlantic following the outbreak of the Second World war on Sept 3<sup>rd</sup> 1939.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: black;\">  </span><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">Despite the outbreak of hostilities, the raider was not allowed to commence warfare against Allied shipping, but was rather ordered on September 5 to avoid all contact with other shipsr. So Langsdorff kept clear of shipping routes, crossing the equator on September 8 and taking up station in a seldom-frequented area of the South Atlantic.<o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: black;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-lG-wH-ceJnc/Tsv0wcXsTOI/AAAAAAAAJCE/EamII6CNCG8/s1600/imagesCA8YSH22.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-lG-wH-ceJnc/Tsv0wcXsTOI/AAAAAAAAJCE/EamII6CNCG8/s400/imagesCA8YSH22.jpg\" height=\"395\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">On September 11, Graf Spee's Arado seaplane, on a routine recognizance flight, spotted the British heavy cruiser HMS Cumberland on an intercept course with the German ships. The British lookouts did not spot the plane, which was able to alert Langsdorff to change course and avoid detection. Cumberland continued on her way from Freetown to Rio de Janeiro, none the wiser. Graf Spee remained in a holding pattern north of the River Platte - Cape of Good Hope shipping route, refueling twice from Altmark. <br />\n<br />\nOn September 26, Langsdorff finally received new orders. Her was to commence hostilities immediately, but with several restrictions: he was to attack only British ships, and not French ships. Actions with enemy warships were to be avoided, so as to not risk his ship. <o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: black;\">  </span><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">Langsdorff <span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp;</span>headed towards the coast of Brazil, to disrupt the flow of meat and grain to Britain along the shipping routes off Pernambuco. <span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp;</span>75 miles northeast of the Brazilian port of Pernambuco, Graf Spee found her first victim just before noon on September 30. The captain of the 5050-ton freighter SS Clement spotted an approaching warship, and thought it was the British cruiser HMS Ajax.&nbsp;</span></span><br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"><br /></span></span>\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">But it was Graf Spee, who's Arado 196 seaplane was launched, and few machine gun bullets were sprayed at the bridge of the freighter. Clement's captain, F.C.P. Harris, was told to stop engines immediately, and order his crew to the boats , without sending a distress message. <span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp;</span>Capt Harris disobeyed and sent a distress message. <span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp;A few rounds from Graf Spee</span> sank the abandoned freighter.<o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: black;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-OEiERZ7bI5I/Tsv02CslF2I/AAAAAAAAJCM/HSFE_bKmp3k/s1600/imagesCA81BCDN.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-OEiERZ7bI5I/Tsv02CslF2I/AAAAAAAAJCM/HSFE_bKmp3k/s400/imagesCA81BCDN.jpg\" height=\"435\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">The sea was calm, so Langsdorff took captain Harris, his chief engineer, and a hand injured while abandoning ship on board the Graf Spee, while the rest of the crew were given the correct course back to the South American port of Maceio, all reaching that location safely the next day.&nbsp;</span></span><br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"><br /></span></span>\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">After treating the wounded man and questioning Harris, Langsdorff stopped the Greek steamer SS Papelemos. Her captain promised not to send a signal until reaching the Cape Verde Islands (a promise which he did not keep), so the three British men were transferred to the neutral freighter and Graf Spee went on her way. <br style=\"mso-special-character: line-break;\" /> <br style=\"mso-special-character: line-break;\" /> </span></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">Knowing that Clement in defiance of his orders , had gotten off a radio distress signal, Langsdorff took the Graf Spee off at high speed, choosing the Cape of Good Hope - Europe route as his next hunting ground. In that shipping route on October 5 Graf Spee found the British freighter SS Newton Beach (4650-tons) with a cargo of corn. The ship was stopped and a prize crew put on board so she could be used as a source of supplies, but not before a distress message was transmitted, again in defiance of his orders. </span></span></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"><span style=\"color: blue; font-size: large;\">In war, defiance can mean instant death, yet Langsdoff was merciful.</span> </span></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-U622fQNnf7w/Tsv5N3C0hBI/AAAAAAAAJC8/fyYc_PTnYE4/s1600/imagesCAD0W6G3.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-U622fQNnf7w/Tsv5N3C0hBI/AAAAAAAAJC8/fyYc_PTnYE4/s400/imagesCAD0W6G3.jpg\" height=\"277\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n</div>\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">Another British merchant ship heard this call, and passed it on later in the day to the HMS Cumberland. This was the worst case scenario for the Germans: a powerful British warship was in the area, the location of the raider was known, and heavy Allied reinforcements could be rapidly dispatched from Dakar, the West Indies, and Pernambuco to track down the raider within a few days.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: black;\">  </span><br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">Heading east in the company of her prize, Graf Spee surprised the British steamer Ashlea (4220-tons) on October 7, which was loaded with sugar.&nbsp;</span></span><br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"><br /></span></span>\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">Her radio operator had no chance to send a message, and the ship was boarded. The Germans gained useful intelligence when her captain, C. Pottinger, failed to destroy his confidential instructions from the Admiralty. Clement's captain had made the same mistake, and the German raider was now in possession, among other valuable documents, of a complete copy of the code given by the Admiraly to merchant ships. Langsdorff now had Ashlea's crew was put onto Newton Beach, and Ashlea was sunk with scuttling charges.<o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; mso-ansi-language: EN;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: black;\">  </span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;,&quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%; mso-ansi-language: EN; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\"><span style=\"color: black;\">On the evening of the 10th, Graf Spee approached the British liner Huntsman (8200-tons), on passage from Calcutta to London with a cargo of tea. The liner's captain, A.H. Brown, mistook Graf Spee for a British cruiser, and allowed her to approach. The Germans then sent a signal threatening to open fire if the radio were used. Unwilling to risk the lives of his crew, Brown complied, and a prize crew took over Huntsman. Returning to the waiting area outside the sea-lanes, Graf Spee refueled from Altmark. <span style=\"background: yellow; mso-highlight: yellow;\"><span style=\"mso-spacerun: yes;\">&nbsp;</span></span>Her captain joined the Graf Spee, while the rest of her crew was put on Altmark, and the ship was scuttled.</span></span></div>\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;,&quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%; mso-ansi-language: EN; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"></span></span><br />\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;,&quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%; mso-ansi-language: EN; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"></span></span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<span lang=\"EN\" style=\"color: #3b491f; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;,&quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%; mso-ansi-language: EN; mso-fareast-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;;\"><span style=\"color: black;\"><a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-eDWx13J-0QA/TsvzudjwZrI/AAAAAAAAJBE/LdPi27pAtE8/s1600/clangsdorff.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em;
