How then can you hope for victory? Even now, it is not loo late for making peace and that is the way to rule your kingdom, making the Pandavas, your powerful brothers, friends instead of enemies. Destruction awaits you if you insult Dhananjaya and Krishna, who are none other than Nara and Narayana.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana took leave and went to his tent, but he could not sleep that night.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The battle was resumed the next morning. Bhishma arrayed the Kaurava forces in a strong formation. So did Dhrishtadyumna for the Pandava army. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GSQ8CbRlq1M/TsJj1lASYNI/AAAAAAAAIf4/OBxu7sy4FHo/s1600/imagesCAN23SCQ.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"272\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GSQ8CbRlq1M/TsJj1lASYNI/AAAAAAAAIf4/OBxu7sy4FHo/s320/imagesCAN23SCQ.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhima stood at the head of the advance lines as usual. And Sikhandin, Dhrishtadyumna and Satyaki stood behind, securely guarding the main body, aided by other generals. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Dharmaputra and the twin brothers held the rear. Bhishma bent his bow and discharged his shafts. The Pandava army suffered greatly under the grandsire's attack.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Dhananjaya saw this and retaliated by fierce shafts aimed at Bhishma. Duryodhana went to Drona and complained bitterly according to his custom. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Drona upbraided him severely: \"Obstinate prince, you talk without understanding. You are ignorant of the Pandavas' strength. We are doing our best.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Drona's powerful attack on the Pandava army was too much for Satyaki who was meeting it and Bhima therefore turned his attentions to Drona. The battle grew fiercer still. Drona, Bhishma and Salya made a combined attack on Bhima. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-KaAHTOdYxNw/TsJj9RA_HxI/AAAAAAAAIgA/Jn5aIpVX1x8/s1600/imagesCANUSVD6.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"239\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-KaAHTOdYxNw/TsJj9RA_HxI/AAAAAAAAIgA/Jn5aIpVX1x8/s320/imagesCANUSVD6.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Sikhandin supported Bhima by pouring a shower of arrows on Bhishma. As soon as Sikhandin stepped in, Bhishma turned away. For Sikhandin was born a girl, and Bhishma's principles did not permit him to attack a woman. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">In the end, this same objection proved to be the cause of Bhishma's death. When Drona saw Bhishma turn away, he attacked Sikhandin fiercely and compelled him to withdraw.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">There was a promiscuous battle the whole of the morning of the fifth day, and the slaughter was terrific. In the after noon, Duryodhana sent a large force to oppose Satyaki. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">But Satyaki destroyed it completely and advanced to attack Bhurisravas. Bhurisravas, who was a powerful opponent, put Satyaki's men to fight, and pressed Satyaki himself so fiercely that he was in distress. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Satyaki's ten sons saw their father's plight and sought to relieve him by launching an offensive against Bhurisravas, but Bhurisravas undaunted by numbers, opposed the combined attack and was not to be shaken. His well-aimed darts broke their weapons and they were all slain, strewn on the field like so many tall trees struck down by lightning. Satyaki, wild with rage and grief, drove forward at a furious pace to slay Bhurisravas. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-UZdmlYUF4b8/TsJkDr_XapI/AAAAAAAAIgI/ay20zblnGlg/s1600/imagesCAOQUXFK.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"320\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-UZdmlYUF4b8/TsJkDr_XapI/AAAAAAAAIgI/ay20zblnGlg/s320/imagesCAOQUXFK.jpg\" width=\"252\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The chariots of the two warriors dashed against each other and crumbled to pieces. And the warriors stood face to face with sword and shield in desperate single combat.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Then, Bhima came and took away Satyaki by force into his chariot and drove away. For Bhima knew that Bhurisravas was an unrivalled swordsman and he did not want Satyaki to be slain.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna killed thousands of warriors that evening. The soldiers, dispatched against him by Duryodhana, perished like moths in the fire. As the sun went down and Bhishma gave orders to cease fighting, the princes on the Pandava army surrounded Arjuna and greeted him with loud cries of admiration and victory.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The armies on both sides retired to camp, along with the tired horses and elephants. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; text-transform: uppercase;\">The Sixth Day</span></b><span style=\"color: black;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">ACCORDING to Yudhishthira's order Dhrishtadyumna arrayed the Pandava army in makara (fish) formation for the sixth day's battle. The Kaurava army was arrayed in krauncha (heron) formation. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-gIJH_9mDHnQ/TsJkJ7ztYJI/AAAAAAAAIgQ/TwSw9tfWkW8/s1600/imagesCAO0Z6PO.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"298\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-gIJH_9mDHnQ/TsJkJ7ztYJI/AAAAAAAAIgQ/TwSw9tfWkW8/s400/imagesCAO0Z6PO.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">We know, how, similarly, names were given to physical exercise, asanas, or postures. Vyuha was the general name for battle array. Which Vyuha was best for any particular occasion, depended on the requirements of the offensive and defensive plans of the day. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">What the strength and composition of the forces arrayed should be and what positions they should take up were decided upon, according to the situation as it developed from time to time. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The sixth day was marked by a prodigious slaughter, even in the first part of the morning. Drona's charioteer was killed and Drona took the reins of the horses himself and used his bow as well. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Great was the destruction he effected. He went about like fire among cotton heaps. The formations of both armies were soon broken and indiscriminate and fierce fighting went on. Blood flowed in torrents and the field was covered by dead bodies of soldiers, elephants and horses and the debris of chariots.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhimasena pierced the enemy's lines to seek out Duryodhana's brothers and finish them. They, for their part, did not wait to be sought, but rushed on him, in a combined attack from all sides. He was attacked by Duhsasana, Durvishaha, Durmata, Jaya, Jayatsena, Vikarna, Chitrasena, Sudarsana, Charuchitra, Suvarma, Dushkarna and others, all together. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhimasena, who did not know what fear was, stood up and fought them all. They desired to take him prisoner and he to kill them all on the spot. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The battle raged fiercely, even like the ancient battle between the gods and the asuras. Suddenly, the son of Pandu lost his patience and jumped down from his chariot, mace in band, and made straight on foot for the sons of Dhritarashtra, in hot haste to slay them.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When Dhrishtadyumna saw Bhima's chariot disappear in the enemy lines, he was alarmed and rushed to prevent disaster. He reached Bhima's car, but found it was occupied only by the charioteer and Bhima was not in it. With tears in his eyes, he asked the charioteer: \"Visoka, where is Bhima dearer to me than life?\" Dhrishtadyumna naturally thought Bhima had fallen.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Visoka bowed and said to the son of Drupada: \"The son of Pandu asked me to stay here and, without waiting for my reply rushed forward on foot, mace in hand, into the enemy ranks.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-gZBxCs2w3yA/TsJkruGZSbI/AAAAAAAAIgY/zmaPLAg6tQI/s1600/imagesCAQHH4Z6.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-gZBxCs2w3yA/TsJkruGZSbI/AAAAAAAAIgY/zmaPLAg6tQI/s400/imagesCAQHH4Z6.jpg\" width=\"307\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Fearing that Bhima would be overpowered and killed Dhrishtadyumna drove his chariot into the enemy lines in search of Bhimasena, whose path was marked by the bodies of slain elephants. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When Dhrishtadyumna found Bhima, he saw him surrounded on all sides by enemies fighting from their chariots. Bhima stood against them all, mace in hand, wounded all over and breathing fire. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Dhrishtadyumna embraced him and took him into his chariot and proceeded to pick out the shafts that had stuck in his body. Duryodhana now ordered his warriors to attack Bhimasena and Dhrishtadyumna and not to wait for them to attack or challenge. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Accordingly, they made a combined attack even though they were not inclined to engage themselves in further fighting. Dhrishtadyumna had a secret weapon, which he had obtained from Dronacharya and, discharging it, threw the enemy forces into a stupor. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">But Duryodhana then joined the fray and discharged weapons to counter the stupor weapons of Dhrishtadyumna. Just then, reinforcements sent by Yudhishthira arrived. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">A force of twelve chariots with their retinue led by Abhimanyu came upon the scene to support Bhima. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Dhrishtadyumna was greatly relieved when he saw this. Bhimasena had also by now refreshed himself and was ready to renew the fight. He got into Kekaya's chariot and took up his position along with the rest. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Drona, however, was terrible that day. He killed Dhrishtadyumna's charioteer and horses and smashed his chariot and Drupada's son had to seek a place in Abhimanyu's car. The Pandava forces began to waver and Drona was cheered by the Kaurava army.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Indiscriminate mass fighting and slaughter went on that day. At one time, Bhima and Duryodhana met face to face. The usual exchange of hot words took place and was followed by a great battle of archery. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana was hit and fell unconscious. Kripa extricated him with great skill and took him away in his own chariot. Bhishma personally arrived at the spot now and led the attack and scattered the Pandava forces. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The sun was sinking, but the battle was continued for an hour yet and the fighting was fierce and many thousands perished. Then the day's battle ceased. Yudhishthira was glad that Dhrishtadyumna and Bhima returned to camp alive.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; text-transform: uppercase;\">The Seventh Day</span></b><span style=\"color: black;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">DURYODHANA, wounded all over and suffering greatly, went to Bhishma and said: <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"The battle had been going against us every day. Our formations are broken and our warriors are being slain in large numbers. You are looking on doing nothing.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The grandsire soothed Duryodhana with comforting words: <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Why do you let yourself be disheartened? Here are all of us, Drona, Salya, Kritavarma, Aswatthama, Vikarna, Bhagadatta, Sakuni, the two brothers of Avanti, the Trigarta chief, the king of Magadha, and Kripacharya. When these great warriors are here, ready to give up their lives for you, why should you feel downhearted? Get rid of this mood of dejection.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Saying this, he issued orders for the day.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"See there,\" the grandsire said to Duryodhana. \"These thousands of cars, horses and horsemen, great war elephants, and those armed foot soldiers from various kingdoms are all ready to fight for you. With this fine army, you can vanquish even the gods. Fear not.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Thus cheering up the dejected Duryodhana, he gave him a healing balm for his wounds. Duryodhana rubbed it over his numerous wounds and felt relieved.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">He went to the field, heartened by the grandsire's words of confidence. The army was that day arrayed in circular formation. With each war elephant were seven chariots fully equipped.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Each chariot was supported by seven horsemen. To each horseman were attached ten shield bearers. Everyone wore armor. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana stood resplendent like Indra at the center of this great and well-equipped army. Yudhishthira arrayed the Pandava army in vajravyuha. This day's battle was fiercely fought simultaneously at many sectors. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhishma personally opposed Arjuna's attacks. Drona and Virata were engaged with each other at another point. Sikhandin and Aswatthama fought a big battle at another sector. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana and Dhrishtadyumna fought with each other at yet another point. Nakula and Sahadeva attacked their uncle Salya. The Avanti kings opposed Yudhamanyu, while Bhimasena opposed Kritavarma, Chitrasena, Vikarna and Durmarsha. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">There were great battles between Ghatotkacha and Bhagadatta, between Alambasa and Satyaki, between Bhurisravas and Dhrishtaketu, between Yudhishthira and Srutayu and between Chekitana and Kripa. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">In the battle between Drona and Virata, the latter was worsted and he had to climb into the chariot of his son Sanga, having lost his own chariot, horses and charioteer. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Virata's sons Uttara and Sveta had fallen in the first day's battle. On this seventh day, Sanga also was slain just as his father came up to his side. Sikhandin, Drupada's son, was defeated by Aswatthama. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">His chariot was smashed and he jumped down and stood sword and shield in hand. Aswatthama aimed his shaft at his sword and broke it. Sikhandin then whirled the broken sword and hurled it at Aswatthama with tremendous force, but it was met by Aswatthama's arrow. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Sikhandin, badly beaten, got into Satyaki's chariot and retired. In the fight between Satyaki and Alambasa, the former had the worst of it at first but later recovered ground and Alambasa had to flee.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">In the battle between Dhrishtadyumna and Duryodhana, the horses of the latter were killed and he had to alight from his chariot. He, however, continued the fight, sword in hand. Sakuni came then and took the prince away in his chariot. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Kritavarma made a strong attack on Bhima but was worsted. He lost his chariot and horses and acknowledging defeat, fled towards Sakuni's car, with Bhima's arrows sticking all over him, making him look like a porcupine speeding away in the forest.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Vinda and Anuvinda of Avanti were defeated by Yudhamanyu, and their armies were completely destroyed. Bhagadatta attacked Ghatotkacha and put to flight all his supporters. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">But, alone, Ghatotkacha stood and fought bravely. But in the end, he too had to save himself by flight, which gladdened the whole Kaurava army.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Salya attacked his nephews. Nakula's horses were killed and he had to join his brother in the latter's chariot. Both continued the fight from the same car. Salya was hit by Sahadeva's arrow and swooned. The charioteer skilfully drove the car away and saved Salya. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When the Madra king (Salya) was seen retreating from the field Duryodhana's army lost heart and the twin sons of Madri blew their conchs in triumph. Taking advantage of the situation, they inflicted heavy damage on Salya's forces.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">At noon, Yudhishthira led an attack on Srutayu. The latter's well-aimed arrows intercepted Dharmaputra's missiles, and his armor was pierced and he was severely wounded.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Yudhishthira then lost his temper and sent a powerful arrow that pierced Srutayu's breast-plate. That day, Yudhishthira was not his normal self and burnt with anger. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Srutayu's charioteer and horses were killed and the chariot was smashed and he had to flee on foot from the field. This completed the demorahsation of Duryodhana's army. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">In the attack on Kripa, Chekitana, losing his chariot and charioteer, alighted and attacked Kripa's charioteer and horses with mace in hand and killed them. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_S3PSyzjhm0/TsJkwhYr4pI/AAAAAAAAIgg/UKknG-J1VKU/s1600/imagesCAR1X0MQ.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"239\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_S3PSyzjhm0/TsJkwhYr4pI/AAAAAAAAIgg/UKknG-J1VKU/s320/imagesCAR1X0MQ.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Kripa also alighted, and standing on the ground, discharged his arrows. Chekitana was badly hit. He then whirled his mace and hurled it at Kripacharya,<b> </b>but the latter was able to intercept it with his own<b> </b>arrow. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Thereupon they closed with each other, sword in hand. Both were wounded and fell on the ground, when Bhima came and took Chekitana away in his chariot. Sakuni similarly took wounded Kripa away in his car. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Ninety-six arrows of Dhrishtaketu struck Bhurisravas. And the great warrior was like a sun radiating glory, as the arrows, all sticking in his breast-plate, shone bright around his radiant face. Even in that condition, he compelled Dhrishtaketu to admit defeat and retire. Three of Duryodhana's brothers attacked Abhimanyu who inflicted a heavy defeat on them but spared their lives, because Bhima had sworn to kill them. Thereupon, Bhishma attacked Abhimanyu.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna saw this and said to his illustrious charioteer: \"Krishna, drive the car towards Bhishma.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">At that moment, the other Pandavas also joined Arjuna. But the grandsire was able to hold his own against all five until the sunset, and the battle was suspended for the day. And the warriors of both sides, weary and wounded, retired to their tents for rest and for having their injuries attended to.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">After this, for an hour, soft music was played, soothing the warriors to their rest. That hour was spent, says the poet, without a word about war or hatred. It was an hour of heavenly bliss, and it was a glad sight to see. One can see herein what the great lesson of the Mahabharata is.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-JxJhChSBikk/TsJk1ZIzCfI/AAAAAAAAIgo/baMcGEQZ48s/s1600/imagesCARB32PN.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"239\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-JxJhChSBikk/TsJk1ZIzCfI/AAAAAAAAIgo/baMcGEQZ48s/s320/imagesCARB32PN.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" class=\"MsoNormalTable\" style=\"mso-cellspacing: 1.5pt; mso-yfti-tbllook: 1184; width: 100%;\"><tbody>\n<tr style=\"mso-yfti-firstrow: yes; mso-yfti-irow: 0;\">   <td style=\"background-color: transparent; border: rgb(0, 0, 0); padding: 0.75pt;\"><div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%; text-transform: uppercase;\">The Eighth Day</span></b><span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">WHEN the eighth day dawned, Bhishma arrayed his army in tortoise   formation. Yudhishthira said to Dhrishtadyumna:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"See there, the enemy is in kurma vyuha (tortoise   formation). You have to answer at once with a formation that can break   it.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhrishtadyumna immediately proceeded to his task. The Pandava   forces were arrayed in a three-pronged formation. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhima was at the head of one prong, Satyaki of another, and   Yudhishthira at the crest of the middle division. Our ancestors had developed   the science of war very well. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It was not reduced to writing but was preserved by tradition in   the families of kshatriyas. Armor and tactics were employed suitably to meet   the weapons of offence and the tactics that the enemy used in those days.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Kurukshetra battle was fought some thousands of years ago.   Reading the story of the battle in the Mahabharata, we should not, having the   practice and incidents of modern warfare in mind, reject the Mahabharata   narrative as mere myth with no relation to fact. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Only about a century and a half ago, the English admiral Nelson   fought great sea battles and won undying renown. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The weapons used and the vessels that actually took part in   Nelson's battles, would seem almost weird and even ridiculous if compared   with those of modern naval warfare. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">If a hundred and fifty years can make so much difference, we   must be prepared for very strange things in the procedure and events of a   period, so long back as that of the Mahabharata war.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Another matter to be kept in mind is that we cannot expect, in   the books of poets and literary writers, accurate or full details about   weapons and tactics, although the narrative may be of battles. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Military affairs were in ancient times the sole concern of the   military order, the kshatriyas. Their culture<b> </b>and their training were   entirely their own charge. </span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-08dG6UbB-kI/TsJk7gWp2eI/AAAAAAAAIgw/AcmFAM_1iu4/s1600/imagesCAUFN0O9.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"320\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-08dG6UbB-kI/TsJk7gWp2eI/AAAAAAAAIgw/AcmFAM_1iu4/s320/imagesCAUFN0O9.jpg\" width=\"239\" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The principles and the secrets of warfare and the science and   art of the use of military weapons were handed down from generation to   generation by tradition and personal instruction. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There were no military textbooks and there was not any place for   them in the works of poets and rishis. If a modern novel deals in some   chapters with the treatment and cure of a sick person, we can not expect to   see such details in it as might interest a medical man. No author would care,   even if he were able, to include scientific details in his story. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">So, we cannot hope to find in the epic of Vyasa, precise details   as to what is tortoise formation or lotus formation. We have no explanation   as to how one could, by discharging a continuous stream of arrows, build a   defence around himself or intercept and cut missiles in transit, or how one   could be living when pierced all over by arrows, or how far the armor worn by   the soldiers and officers could protect them against missiles or what were   the ambulance arrangements or how the dead were disposed of. </span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-tgvgskkgP-4/TsJlBT3gkPI/AAAAAAAAIg4/GLxL9iY_lKE/s1600/imagesCAVLGFNS.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"320\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-tgvgskkgP-4/TsJlBT3gkPI/AAAAAAAAIg4/GLxL9iY_lKE/s320/imagesCAVLGFNS.jpg\" width=\"201\" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">All these things appertaining to ancient war, however   interesting, will have to be in the realm of the unknown in spite of the   vivid narrative we have in the Mahabharata epic.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhima killed eight of Dhritarashtra's sons early in the battle   that day. Duryodhana's heart lost courage before this. It seemed to his   friends as if Bhimasena would complete his revenge this very day, even as he   swore in the assembly ball, where the great outrage was enacted. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Arjuna had a great bereavement in this day's battle. His dear   son Iravan was killed. This son of Arjuna by his Naga wife had come and   joined the Pandava forces at Kurukshetra. Duryodhana sent his friend, the Rakshasa   Alambasa, to oppose the Naga warrior.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Iravan was slain after a fierce fight. When Arjuna heard this,   he broke down completely. Said he turning to Vasudeva: \"Vidura had   indeed told us plainly that both sides would be plunged in grief unbearable.   What are we doing all this wretched destruction up on one another for? Just   for the sake of property. After all this killing, what joy are we or they   likely to find in the end? O Madhusudana, I now see why the far seeing   Yudhishthira said he would be content if Duryodhana would give five villages   to us, keeping everything else to himself and he would not resort to fighting   if that were agreed to. Duryodhana, in his obstinate folly, refused to give   even these five villages and so, these great sins have to be committed on   both sides. I continue fighting only because men would otherwise think me a   coward, who could submit tamely to wrong. When I see the dead warriors lying   on the field, my heart is filled with unbearable anguish. Oh, how wicked we   are to carry on in this miserable, sinful way.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Seeing Iravan killed, Ghatotkacha uttered a loud war-cry which   made all the assembled soldiers tremble. And with his division, he fell upon   the Kaurava army ferociously. So great was the destruction he wrought that at   many points the Kaurava formation was broken. </span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-_8zINwf6eWA/TsJlHQmC_AI/AAAAAAAAIhA/co5hgr7Ri7A/s1600/imagesCAWN4T75.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"239\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-_8zINwf6eWA/TsJlHQmC_AI/AAAAAAAAIhA/co5hgr7Ri7A/s320/imagesCAWN4T75.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Seeing this, Duryodhana personally led an attack on Bhima's son.   The king of Vanga joined Duryodhana with his elephants. Duryodhana fought   most bravely on this eighth day of the battle. He killed a great number of warriors   on Ghatotkacha's side. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ghatotkacha hurled a javelin which would have ended Duryodhana's   career but for the Vanga chief's prompt intervention with one of his   elephants. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The missile hit the beast, which fell dead, and Duryodhana was   saved. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhishma was anxious about Duryodhana and sent a large force   under Drona to support the Kaurava prince. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many were the veterans who were in this force that attacked   Ghatotkacha. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">So tumultuous and fierce was the fight at this sector of the   battle that Yudhishthira feared for Ghatotkacha's safety and sent Bhimasena   to his aid. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Then the battle became even fiercer than before. Sixteen of   Duryodhana's brothers perished on this day.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</td>  </tr>\n<tr style=\"mso-yfti-irow: 1; mso-yfti-lastrow: yes;\">   <td style=\"background-color: transparent; border: rgb(0, 0, 0); padding: 0.75pt;\"><div align=\"center\">\n<table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" class=\"MsoNormalTable\" style=\"mso-cellspacing: 0in; mso-padding-alt: 0in 0in 0in 0in; mso-yfti-tbllook: 1184; width: 100%;\"><tbody>\n<tr style=\"mso-yfti-firstrow: yes; mso-yfti-irow: 0; mso-yfti-lastrow: yes;\">     <td style=\"background-color: transparent; border: rgb(0, 0, 0); padding: 0in; width: 100%;\" width=\"100%\"></td>    </tr>\n</tbody></table>\n</div>\n</td>  </tr>\n</tbody></table>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; text-transform: uppercase;\">The Ninth Day</span></b><span style=\"color: black;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">ON the morning of the ninth day, before the battle began, Duryodhana was closeted with the grandsire. He gave vent to his bitter feelings of disappointment over the way the battle was going. He uttered words that were like the sharp spears and pained the grandsire greatly but the latter was patient and said sadly:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Like ghee on the sacrificial fire I am pouring my life out for you. Why do you seek to mortify me, who have been doing my very utmost for you? You speak like a man of no understanding, not knowing what is right and what is wrong. They say that, when a man is nearing his death, the tree appears to him to be made of gold. You see things now, not as they are. Your vision is clouded. You are now reaping the harvest of the hatred you deliberately sowed. The best course for you are to go on fighting, as well as you can. This is also the plain path of duty. It is not possible for me to fight Sikhandin, for I can never raise my hand against a woman. Nor can I with my hands kill the Pandavas, for my mind revolts against it. I will do everything barring these two and fight all the warriors opposed to you. Nothing is gained by losing heart. Fight as a kshatriya should and honor will be yours whatever the events.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Saying thus to Duryodhana and cheering him up with wise and affectionate words, Bhishma proceeded to issue instructions for arraying the forces for the day's battle. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana was heartened. He sent for Duhsasana and said to him: \"Brother, put forth all our strength in today's battle. I am convinced, the grandsire is fighting on our side with his whole heart. It is only against Sikhandin, he says, he cannot use his weapons. We should see that he is not exposed to Sikhandin's attacks, for you know, even a wild dog can kill a lion if the latter scorns to fight back.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">There was a great fight between Abhimanyu and Alambasa. Abhimanyu demonstrated that his valor was no less than his illustrious father's. Alambasa had to flee on foot to save himself. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">There were fierce combats between Satyaki and Aswatthama and between Drona and Arjuna. Thereafter, all the Pandavas attacked the grandsire and Duryodhana sent Duhsasana to support the old warrior. Bhishma fought furiously and beat the Pandavas back. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The Pandava forces were thoroughly demoralised and were flying hither and thither, like cattle that had lost their way in the forest. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Krishna halted the chariot and said to Arjuna: \"Partha, you and your brothers were looking forward to this day, after thirteen years. Do not hesitate to kill the grandsire. Remember the duty of a soldier.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna bent his head down and, without looking up, replied: \"I would much rather have continued to be an exile in the forest than kill the grandsire and the teachers whom I love, but I shall obey you. Drive on.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna's heart was not in the fight. Unwillingly and in great distress of mind, he proceeded to the combat. Bhishma, on<b> </b>the other hand, burnt fiercely like the noonday sun.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When the army saw Arjuna's chariot proceed towards Bhishma, it regained courage and order once again prevailed. Bhishma's arrows came thick and fast and covered the advancing chariot so completely that neither horses nor vehicles could be seen. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Krishna was unperturbed and drove on with circumspection and skill. Arjuna's shafts hit Bhishma's bow and shattered it many times. But the grandsire went on renewing his weapon.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"You are not fighting, Arjuna, as you should!\" exclaimed Krishna, and jumped down in a rage from the chariot and, taking up his discus, he advanced towards the grandsire. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhishma saw Vasudeva approaching.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Hail, O Lotus-eyed One!\" he cried. \"Blessed am I to be separated from the body by you! Come, come!\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna jumped down from the chariot and, rushing forward overtook and held Krishna, casting both his arms around him. \"Stop, Krishna,\" he cried. \"Do not break your pledge. You have promised not to use weapons in this battle. This is my work. I shall not fail. I shall send my arrows and kill the beloved grandsire myself. Pray, mount the car and take the reins.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna took Krishna back and the battle was resumed. The Pandava forces had been handled roughly, but now the sun was down in the west and the fighting ended for the day.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; text-transform: uppercase;\">The Passing Of Bhishma</span></b><span style=\"color: black;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">IT was the tenth day of the battle. Keeping Sikhandin in front of him, Arjuna attacked Bhishma. When Sikhandin's darts pierced his breast, sparks flew from the grandsire's eyes. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">For a moment the old warrior's anger rose like flaming fire and his eyes glared as if to consume Sikhandin. But, at once, the grandsire<b> </b>restrained himself. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">He decided not to be provoked into fighting Sikhandin, who was born a woman and to strike whom it seemed unworthy of a warrior.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">He knew, however, his end was near and calmed himself. Sikhandin went on discharging his arrows, not minding the battle of emotions in his opponent's mind. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna also steeled his heart, and from behind Sikhandin aimed arrows at the weak points in Bhishma's armor, even while the grandsire stood still.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhishma smiled as the arrows continued to come down thick on him, and turning to Duhsasana, said: \"Ah, these are Arjuna's arrows! These cannot be Sikhandin's, for they burn my flesh as the crab's young ones tear their mother's body.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Thus did the grandsire look upon his dear pupil's arrows and, while saying this to Duhsasana, he took up a javelin and hurled it at Arjuna. Arjuna met it with three arrows which cut it to pieces even as it was speeding through the air. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhishma then decided to end the combat and made as if to dismount from his chariot, sword and shield in hand. But before he could do so, his shield was cut to pieces by Arjuna's arrows. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">With arrows sticking all over his body so thickly that there was not even an inch of intervening space, Bhishma fell headlong to the ground from his chariot. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">As he fell, the gods, who looked on from above, folded their hands in reverent salutation and a gentle breeze, laden with fragrance and cool raindrops, swept over the battlefield.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Thus fell the great and good Bhishma, the son of Ganga, who came on earth to hallow it and all it bears. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The blameless hero who, unasked, made the great renunciation to give joy to his father. The undefeated bowman who had humbled the pride of Rama of the axe. The selfless worker for righteousness' sake, thus repaid his debt to Duryodhana, and lay wounded to death sanctifying with his life-blood the battlefield. As the grandsire fell, the hearts of the Kauravas also fell along with him.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhishma's body did not touch the ground, on account of the arrows sticking out all over his body. His body shone more brightly than ever before, as it lay as on a bed of honor, supported by the shafts that had pierced his flesh. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Both armies ceased fighting and all the warriors came running and crowded round the great hero, who lay on his bed of arrows. The kings of the earth stood with bowed heads round him, as the gods round Brahma.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"My head hangs down unsupported,\" said the grandsire. The princes who stood near, ran and brought cushions. The old warrior rejected them with a smile and, turning towards Arjuna said: \"Dear son Partha, give me a cushion befitting a warrior.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When Arjuna, whose arrows were just then burning the grandsire's flesh, heard those words addressed to him, he took three arrows from out of his quiver and so placed them that the grandsire's<b> </b>head found support on their points. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Princes,\" said Bhishma addressing the assembled chiefs, \"Arjuna's arrows were indeed what my head required to be supported on. This pillow gives me satisfaction. Now, I must lie thus until the sun turns north. My soul will not depart till then. ( <span style=\"background-color: yellow; color: red; font-size: large;\">THIS IS THE ICHAMRIYTHYU DATE OF MAKARAVILAKKU AT SABARIMALA , KERALA</span> ) When I pass away, those of you who may be alive then may come and see me.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Then the grandsire turned again to Arjuna and said: \"I am tormented with thirst. Get me some drinking water.\" At once, Arjuna raised his bow, and drawing, it to the ear, shot a shaft down into the earth near the grandsire on his right side.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Upon the opening made by the arrow, there gushed a stream of pure sweet water to the very lips of the dying man. Ganga came up, says the poet, to quench her dear son's burning thirst. Bhishma drank and was happy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Duryodhana, may you be wise!\" said Bhishma, addressing the Kaurava prince. \"Did you see how Arjuna brought me water to quench my thirst? Who else in this world can do such a deed? Make peace with him without further delay. May the war cease with my exit. Listen to me, son, make peace with the Pandavas.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The grandsire's words did not please Duryodhana. Even when dying, the patient does not like medicine. He objects to the bitter taste. All the princes retired to their camps.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" class=\"MsoNormalTable\" style=\"mso-cellspacing: 1.5pt; mso-yfti-tbllook: 1184; width: 100%;\"><tbody>\n<tr style=\"mso-yfti-firstrow: yes; mso-yfti-irow: 0;\">   <td style=\"background-color: transparent; border: rgb(0, 0, 0); padding: 0.75pt;\"><div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%; text-transform: uppercase;\">Karna and the Grandsire</span></b><span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">WHEN he learnt that Bhishma lay wounded and dying, Karna hurried   to the place and fell at his feet and said:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Eldest of the race. Radha's son, who, through no fault of   his, incurred your great displeasure, humbly prostrates himself before   you.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When after humble salutation Karna stood up, the grandsire,   greatly moved, tenderly placed his hand on Karna's head and blessed him.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"You are not Radha's son, young man,\" he said in   loving tones: \"You are Kuntidevi's own first born. Narada, who knows all   the secrets of the world, himself revealed this to me. Son of Surya, truly I entertained   no dislike for you. But I was grieved to see your increasing hatred of the   Pandavas although they gave you no cause for it. I know and admire your valor   and your open handedness. And I know also that you belong to the class of   Phalguna and Krishna in prowess. It is proper that you befriend the Pandavas.   Therein lies the right path for you who are their brother. With the closing   of my part in this war, may the chapter of your enmity also close. This is my   wish, Karna.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Karna listened respectfully and replied: \"Grandsire I know   I am Kunti's son, and not charioteer born. But I have eaten Duryodhana's salt   and must be true to him, to be true to my own lineage. It is impossible for   me to go over to the Pandavas now. You must permit me to repay with my life,   if it so be the debt I owe to Duryodhana for his love and trust. I have erred   greatly in word and deed. You must forgive me for it all and give me your   blessings.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The great acharya, who knew all the laws of right conduct and   what Karna said, replied: \"Do reflect for a while and then do as you   wish, for that is the right way.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even when Bhishma was mortally wounded and lay dying, the battle   did not cease. Discarding the grandsire's words of wisdom, the Kauravas   resumed the battle.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Deprived of Bhishma's leadership, the Kaurava forces felt like   sheep without a shepherd when Bhishma no longer led them. Indeed, even as   Bhishma fell wounded, the men shouted:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"O Karna, you are the one left to lead and protect   us.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Kaurava warriors felt that, if but Karna would agree to take   up the command, victory was certain. During the first ten days when Bhishma   led the forces, the son of Surya kept away from the battle. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">As already narrated, deeply hurt at the grandsire's contempt,   Karna had said: \"So long as you are up fighting, I shall keep aloof. If   you slay the Pandavas and bring victory to Duryodhana, I shall be glad. And I   shall then, taking the king's leave, go to the forest. But, if you be   defeated and go to the abode of the brave, I who am not deemed by you as an   adhiratha (master of chariot warfare) will ride my chariot and oppose those   whom you deem to be of greater prowess than myself. And defeating them, bring   victory to Duryodhana.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus had Karna sworn and, with Duryodhana's consent, kept aloof   from the battle during the first ten days. Now he went on foot to Bhishma who   lay on his bed of arrows waiting for his end and, saluting him, addressed him   thus: <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Veteran grandsire, vanquisher of Parasurama, you lie on   the field of battle, struck down by Sikhandin. If you, who had reached the   summit of right living and were an embodiment of purity itself, must lie   wounded in this manner, it is clear that no one can attain in this world what   he deserves by his merit. You were the one boat on which the Kaurava princes   depended for crossing the flood of their troubles. Heavy indeed will be the   blows that the Pandavas will now deal at the Kauravas and great will be their   consequent distress. Like fire and wind burning down the forest, Arjuna and   Krishna will destroy the army of Kauravas. This is certain. Turn your   gracious eyes on me and bless me, who have accepted the command of the   forces.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhishma gave his blessings to Karna.\"You are like the good   earth to the seeds, like rain clouds to living beings, ever dependable, firm   in your loyalty. Serve Duryodhana and save him. You vanquished the Kambojas   for him. You put down the Kiratas of the Himalayan fastnesses for him. You   fought the Girivrajas on his behalf and defeated them. Many more things you   have accomplished for him. Take charge of the Kaurava army now as your own   rich possession and guard it well. May you lead Duryodhana's forces to   success! May you have every good fortune! Fight your enemies, go.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Karna, having received the benediction of the grandsire, mounted   his chariot and rode to the battlefield. When the valorous Karna entered the   field on his war chariot, Duryodhana's joys knew no bounds. His sorrow, at   having lost Bhishma, was in some degree alleviated. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</td>  </tr>\n<tr style=\"mso-yfti-irow: 1; mso-yfti-lastrow: yes;\">   <td style=\"background-color: transparent; border: rgb(0, 0, 0); padding: 0.75pt;\"><div align=\"center\">\n<table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" class=\"MsoNormalTable\" style=\"mso-cellspacing: 0in; mso-padding-alt: 0in 0in 0in 0in; mso-yfti-tbllook: 1184; width: 100%;\"><tbody>\n<tr style=\"mso-yfti-firstrow: yes; mso-yfti-irow: 0; mso-yfti-lastrow: yes;\">     <td style=\"background-color: transparent; border: rgb(0, 0, 0); padding: 0in; width: 100%;\" width=\"100%\"></td>    </tr>\n</tbody></table>\n</div>\n</td>  </tr>\n</tbody></table>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; text-transform: uppercase;\">Drona in Command</span></b><span style=\"color: black;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">DURYODHANA and Karna held counsel as to who should be put in supreme command of the forces.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Well, everyone of these princely warriors fighting on your side is great enough to be put in charge of our forces as supreme commander,\" said Karna. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"All these kings are of equal prowess, strength, energy, skill, courage, valor, ancestry and wisdom. They cannot all be put in joint command and, if any of them be chosen, each of the others would feel hurt and may not put forth his whole strength in the cause. Thereby we stand to suffer. So, my advice is that we install Dronacharya, the teacher of all these princes and warriors, as supreme commander. He indeed is the greatest of all those that carry arms today. No kshatriya equals him in the qualities required for leading our army. Let us therefore install him.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana agreed that this was the right thing to do, and so it was decided.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoBodyTextIndent\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 1em 0in;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana went to Dronacharya and, in the presence of the assembled warriors and princes, bowed and addressed him: <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Revered Master, you are unrivalled among all those assembled here in caste, ancestry, knowledge of sciences, age, wisdom, valor and skill. I beg of you to accept the supreme command. Under your command, this army will be victorious.\" The assembled kings received this proposal with loud cheers and war cries that gladdened Duryodhana's heart.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Drona was installed in due form amidst thunderous acclamation. The praise of courtiers and the sound of trumpets that accompanied the ceremony, made the Kauravas feel as though they had already vanquished the enemy. So great was their enthusiasm and confidence in Drona's leadership. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Drona arrayed the army in circular formation. Karna, who had till then stood aside was now seen moving about in his great chariot on the battlefield and this put new courage and joy into the hearts of the Kaurava soldiers. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The talk went round in the army that the great Bhishma did not wish to slay the sons of Pandu and therefore had not put his whole heart in the fight. But now that Karna was in the field, it was certain that the Pandavas would be destroyed. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Dronacharya was in command for five days of the battle. Though of advanced years, he was everywhere in the field and displayed the fierce energy of a young warrior. Whenever he led an attack, the Pandava forces were scattered like clouds before a storm. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">He personally engaged the greatest warriors on the Pandava side in battle. He fought Satyaki, Bhima, Arjuna, Dhrishtadyumna, Abhimanyu, Drupada and Kasiraja and defeated them on many occasions. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">He harassed and inflicted severe punishment on the Pandava army during the five days he was in command.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" class=\"MsoNormalTable\" style=\"mso-cellspacing: 1.5pt; mso-yfti-tbllook: 1184; width: 100%;\"><tbody>\n<tr style=\"mso-yfti-firstrow: yes; mso-yfti-irow: 0;\">   <td style=\"background-color: transparent; border: rgb(0, 0, 0); padding: 0.75pt;\"><div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%; text-transform: uppercase;\">To Seize Yudhishthira Alive</span></b><span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">AS SOON AS Drona assumed command of the Kaurava forces   Duryodhana, Karna and Duhsasana sat in council and decided on a plan. And   Duryodhana went to Dronacharya to put it in operation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Acharya, we desire that you should capture Yudhishthira   alive and give him over to us. We desire nothing more, not even a total   victory. If you achieve this for us, we shall all be exceedingly satisfied   with your conduct of the war.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When Drona heard Duryodhana address him thus, great was his joy,   for he hated the very idea of slaying the Pandava brothers. Even though, to   fulfil his obligation, the acharya loyally joined the Kaurava side against   the Pandavas, he loved the sons of Kunti and especially the pure-minded   Yudhishthira. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">So, when he heard Duryodhana request that Yudhishthira should be   captured alive, he felt greatly relieved. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Duryodhana, may you be blessed!\" the acharya said.   \"Do you too wish to abstain from killing Yudhishthira? How it gladdens   my heart! Truly, Yudhishthira is one without an enemy and the name   Ajatasatru, which the people have given to Kunti's eldest son, has been   justified by your great decision. When even you have made up your mind that   he should not be killed but should be captured alive, his unrivalled glory   has become ten times enhanced.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"I see, dear Duryodhana, what you intend,\" Drona   continued. \"You wish to defeat the Pandavas in battle and then give them   their share in the kingdom and live in peace and amity with them. I see this   clearly from your desire to capture Yudhishthira alive.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Drona was exceedingly glad and he said again: \"Indeed   Yudhishthira is the most fortunate man on earth. The gods are showering their   favors on Kunti's good son. So has he won the hearts of even enemies.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">But Duryodhana's motives in wishing to take Yudhishthira alive   were far different. And as soon as Drona acceded to his proposal and gave his   pledge that he would do his best to capture Yudhishthira, he began to reveal   his real intentions.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">If Yudhishthira were slain, nothing would be gained by it, and   the anger of the Pandavas would be all the greater. The battle would rage   more fiercely than before. And Duryodhana knew that it would only mean the   utter defeat of his army. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Even if the fight were to be continued relentlessly until both   armies were destroyed, Krishna would still remain alive and he would put   either Draupadi or Kunti in sovereign possession of the kingdom. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">What then was the point in killing Yudhishthira? On the other   hand, if Yudhishthira was captured alive, Duryodhana thought, the war would   end more speedily and victoriously for the Kauravas. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thereafter, he could surely play on Yudhishthira's goodness and   his loyalty to the traditional code of kshatriya conduct. It was pretty   certain he could be drawn into the battle of dice again and sent to the   forests once more. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ten days of fighting had demonstrated to Duryodhana that further   fighting would only result in the destruction of the race, not the fulfilment   of the desires.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When Duryodhana made his motives clear to Drona, the acharya was   greatly disappointed and he cursed Duryodhana in his heart. But whatever the   reason for it, he was glad that Yudhishthira was not to be killed.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The news that Drona had given a solemn assurance to Duryodhana   that he would take Yudhishthir a prisoner, was carried by their spies to the   Pandava army. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Pandavas knew that, when the acharya was determined on   something and gave his pledged word for executing it, his unrivalled eminence   in the art of war and his valor made it a most serious affair. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">So, they soon got busy and so arrayed the forces that   Yudhishthira was never left unsupported. Whatever movements might take place,   they always took care to leave sufficient protection against any surprise   attack on Yudhishthira.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the first day's battle under the leadership of Drona, the   acharya amply demonstrated his great skill and energy. He moved about   destroying the Pandava forces like a fire burning up dry logs. His rapid   movements made the Pandava army feel as if Drona was everywhere at the same   time showering arrows like rain and converting the battlefield into a stage   for the dance of the God of Death. He cut the Pandava army in twain where   Dhrishtadyumna stood. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many were the single combats among renowned warriors. There was   a fierce battle between Sahadeva and Sakuni skilled in illusion warfare. When   their chariots broke, they alighted on the ground. And, like two hills sprung   to life and motion, they struck each other with maces and closed with one   another in single combat. Between Bhima and Vivimsati there was a great   battle in which chariots were broken on both sides. Salya fought his nephew   Nakula and harassed him exceedingly, smiling most provokingly all the time.   But, in the end, Salya had his car smashed and his flag brought down, and he   withdrew admitting defeat.
