I crave your blessings for the fulfilment of my vow,\" said Arjuna to the acharya. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The acharya smiled and said: \"Arjuna, you must first fight and defeat me before you can reach Jayadratha.\" Saying this Drona discharged a shower of arrows on Arjuna's car. Partha also replied with his arrows but these the acharya parried with ease and sent flaming shafts that hit Krishna and Arjuna. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The Pandava then decided to cut Drona's bow and bent his Gandiva for that purpose. Even as he was pulling his bowstring Drona's shaft came and cut the string. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The acharya, still retaining the smile on his face, rained a shower of arrows on Arjuna and his horses and chariot. Arjuna fought back, but the acharya showered his arrows that covered Arjuna and his chariot in darkness.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Krishna saw things were not going at all well and said: \"Partha, no more waste of time. Let us proceed. It is no use fighting this brahmana, who seems to know no fatigue.\" Saying this, Krishna drove Arjuna's chariot to the left of the acharya and proceeded forward.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoBodyTextIndent\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 1em 0in;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Stop, surely you will not proceed without defeating your enemy,\" said Drona.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"You are my guru, not my enemy, O acharya. I am in the position of a son to you. There is no one in the wide world that can defeat you,\" said Arjuna and they proceeded forward at a swift pace bypassing Drona.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Then Arjuna pierced the Bhoja army. Kritavarma and Sudakshina who opposed his passage were defeated. Srutayudha also tried to stop Arjuna's progress. There was a fierce battle in which Srutayudha lost his horses and he hurled his mace at Krishna.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">His mother had obtained this mace as a result of her offering but the condition attached to the boon operated and it came back and struck Srutayudha himself dead. This is the story of the mace.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Parnasa went through penances that pleased Varuna and obtained from that god a boon that her son Srutayudha may not be killed by any enemy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"I shall give your son a divine weapon. Let him use it in all his battles. No enemy will be able to defeat him or kill him. But he should not use the weapon against one who does not fight. If he does, the weapon will recoil and kill him. Saying this, god Varuna gave a mace. Srutayudha, when fighting Arjuna, disregarding the injunction, hurled the mace at Krishna who was not fighting but was only driving Arjuna's chariot. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The missile hit Janardana's chest and immediately rebounded<b> </b>fiercely back to Srutayudha. And like a demon recoiling fatally on the magician, that commits an error in uttering the<b> </b>spell of power that holds it in thrall, it slew Srutayudha and laid him dead on the field, like a great forest tree blown down by a storm.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Then the king of Kamboja led his forces against Arjuna. After a fierce fight, he lay stretched dead on the field like a great flagstaff after the festival is over.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When they saw the strong warriors, Srutayudha and the king of Kamboja, slain, the Kaurava force was in great confusion. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Srutayu and his brother Asrutayu then attacked Partha on both sides trying to save the situation, and greatly harassed him. At one stage of this battle, Arjuna leaned on the flagstaff, dazed with the wounds he received. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">But Krishna spoke to him encouragingly and Arjuna recovered and resumed the fight, slaying the two brothers as well as their two sons who continued the struggle. Arjuna marched on and, killing many more warriors successfully made his way to Jayadratha.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; text-transform: uppercase;\">Borrowed Armor</span></b><span style=\"color: black;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">WHEN Dhritarashtra heard Sanjaya relate the success of Arjuna, he exclaimed: \"Oh Sanjaya! When Janardana came to Hastinapura seeking a settlement, I told Duryodhana that it was a great opportunity and he must not lose it. I told him to make peace with his cousins. 'Kesava has come to do us a good turn. Do not disregard his advice,' I said. But Duryodhana heeded not. What Karna and Duhsasana said seemed to him better advice than mine. The Destroyer entered his mind and he sought his own ruin. Drona deprecated war, so also did Bhishma, Bhurisravas, Kripa and others. But my obstinate son would not listen. Impelled by inordinate ambition, he got entangled in anger and hatred, and invited this ruinous war.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">To Dhritarashtra thus lamenting, Sanjaya said: \"Of what avail are your regrets now? The life-giving water has all run to waste and you now seek to stop the breach. Why did you not prevent the son of Kunti from gambling? Had you done the right thing then, all this great grief would have been stopped at the source. Even later, if you had been firm and stopped your son from his evil ways, this calamity could have been avoided. You saw the evil and yet, against your own sound judgment, you followed the foolish advice of Karna and Sakuni. Kesava, Yudhishthira and Drona do not respect you now as they did before. Vasudeva now knows that your rectitude is only hypocrisy. The Kauravas are now doing their utmost as warriors, but they are unequal to opposing the strength of Arjuna, Krishna, Satyaki and Bhima. Duryodhana has not spared himself. He is putting forth his utmost strength. It is not meet that you should now accuse him or his devoted soldiers.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Dear Sanjaya, I admit my dereliction of duty. What you say is right. No one can change the course of fate. Tell me what happened. Tell me all, be it ever so unpleasant,\" said the old king convulsed with grief. And obedient to the old king's behest, Sanjaya continued his narration. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana was greatly agitated when he saw Arjuna's chariot proceeding triumphantly towards the Sindhu king. He rushed to Drona and complained bitterly:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Arjuna has effected a breach in the great army and has advanced to Jayadratha's position. Seeing our discomfiture, the warriors, protecting the Sindhu king, will surely lose heart. They had believed that it was impossible for Arjuna to get past you and that has now been falsified. He advanced before your eyes and nothing was done to prevent it. You seem indeed bent on helping the Pandavas. I am in great distress of mind. Sir, tell me, in what matter have I offended you? Why are you letting me down in this way? If I had known that you would do this, I should not have asked Jayadratha to stay here. It was a great mistake I committed in not letting him go, as he desired, back to his own country. If Arjuna attacks him, it is not possible for him to escape death. Forgive me. I am talking foolishly, distracted by grief. Do go in person yourself to save the Saindhava.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">To this frantic appeal Drona made answer: \"King, I shall not take offence at your thoughtless and unworthy remarks. You are like a son to me. Aswatthama himself is not dearer! Do what I ask you. Take this coat of armor and, donning it, go and stop Arjuna. I cannot do so for my presence is necessary in this part of the field. See there, the clouds of arrows! The Pandava army is attacking us in great force. Yudhishthira is here unsupported by Arjuna and is this not just the opportunity we wanted? Our very plan has borne fruit and I must now take Yudhishthira prisoner and deliver him to you. I cannot give up this objective and run after Phalguna now. If I go after Arjuna now, our battle array will be hopelessly broken and we shall be lost. Let me put this armor on you. Go in confidence. Do not fear. You have valor, skill and experience. This coat will protect you against all weapons. It will not let any blow pass through your body. Go forth to battle, Duryodhana, in confidence as Indra did, clad in the armor given by Brahma. May victory be yours.\" Duryodhana's confidence was restored and, as the acharya directed, he went, dressed in magic armor and accompanied by a large force of soldiers, to attack Arjuna. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna had crossed the Kaurava army and gone far ahead towards where Jayadratha had been kept for safety. Seeing that the horses were somewhat fatigued, Krishna stopped the chariot and was about to unyoke the tired animals, when the brothers Vinda and Anuvinda came up suddenly and began to attack Arjuna. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">They were defeated and Arjuna scattered their forces and slew them both. After this, Krishna unyoked the chariot and let the horses roll in the mud. The horses rested for a while and were refreshed. Then, they proceeded again according to plan.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Dhananjaya, look behind! There comes the foolhardy Duryodhana. What good luck! Long have you suppressed your anger, and now is the time for you to let yourself go. Here is the man who caused all this grief, delivering himself into your hands. But remember he is a great archer, well-versed in bow lore, and also a keen and strong-limbed fighter.\" Thus said Krishna and they halted to give battle to the Kaurava.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana approached without fear. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"They say, Arjuna, that you have done acts of prowess. I have not seen this myself. Let me see if your courage and your skill are indeed as great as your reputation,\" said Duryodhana to Arjuna as he began to battle.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The combat was fierce indeed and Krishna was surprised. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Partha, I am astonished,\" said Krishna, \"How is it your arrows do not seem to hurt Duryodhana? This is the first time I see the shafts proceeding from the Gandiva bow strike their targets without effect. This is strange, Have your arms lost their power? Or has the Gandiva bow lost its quality? Why do your arrows strike Duryodhana and drop to the ground without piercing him? This is most puzzling.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0M0k04sh4ZA/TsJlXy5_zaI/AAAAAAAAIhY/_fQCZrycDjI/s1600/imagesCAXB97RX.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0M0k04sh4ZA/TsJlXy5_zaI/AAAAAAAAIhY/_fQCZrycDjI/s1600/imagesCAXB97RX.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna smiled and replied: \"I understand. This man has come dressed by Drona in charmed armor. The acharya has taught me the secret of this armor, but this man wears it as a bullock might do. You<b> </b>will see some fun now!\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Saying thus, Arjuna proceeded to shoot his arrows, first depriving Duryodhana of his horses, his charioteer and his car. Then, Arjuna broke his bow and disarmed him completely. There after he sent needle-eye darts which pierced just those parts of Duryodhana's body that were not covered by armor, until he could bear it no longer and turned and fled.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When Duryodhana was thus discomfited, Krishna blew his conch and it sent a thrill of fear in Jayadratha's army. The warriors around the Sindhu king were surprised. They at once got ready in their chariots and Bhurisravas, Chala, Karna, Vrishasena, Kripa, Salya, Aswatthama and Jayadratha, eight of them, arrayed their forces against Arjuna. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; text-transform: uppercase;\">Yudhishthira's Misgivings</span></b><span style=\"color: black;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">WHEN the Pandavas saw Duryodhana proceeding in the direction of Arjuna, they attacked the Kaurava army in force so as to hold Drona and prevent him from going to Jayadratha's rescue. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">So, Dhrishtadyumna led his forces repeatedly against Drona. As a result of all this, the Kaurava army had to fight on three fronts, and was greatly weakened.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Driving his chariot right against Drona's, Dhrishtadyumna attacked him violently. Drona's chestnut horses and the Panchala's dove-colored ones were entangled with one another and presented a picturesque sight like the clouds at sunset. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Dhrishtadyumna threw away his bow and, sword and shield in hand, he sprang upon Drona's chariot. Now standing on the shafts of the vehicle, now on the horses and now on the yoke, he attacked Drona bewilderingly, all the while seeming to scorch him with baleful and bloodshot eyes. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Long did this fight go on. Drona pulled his bow in great wrath and sent a shaft, which would have drunk the Panchala's life but for the unexpected intervention of Satyaki who sent an arrow and diverted the acharya's shaft. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Drona then turned and attacked Satyaki, which enabled the Panchala warriors to take Dhrishtadyumna away. Drona, hissing like a black cobra, his eyes red with anger, advanced on Satyaki who was among the front rank warriors on the Pandava side and who, when he saw Drona desiring battle, went forward to accept the challenge. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Here is the man who, giving up his vocation as a brahmana has taken up the profession of fighting and is causing distress to the Pandavas,\" Satyaki said to his charioteer. \"This man is the principal cause of Duryodhana's arrogance.<b> </b>This man fancies himself a very great soldier and is ever bursting with conceit. I must teach him a lesson. Take the chariot up quickly.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Satyaki's charioteer accordingly lashed the silver-white horses and took the car at a great pace. Satyaki and Drona shot shafts at one another so quick that they covered the sun, and the battlefield was in darkness for a while. The steel shafts swished glimmering like newly-sloughed snakes rushing about.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The chariot hoods and the flagstaffs on both sides were battered down. Drona as well as Satyaki were bleeding profusely. The warriors on either side stood still watching the duel and they did not blow their conchs or raise their war cries or sound their lion-roars. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The Devas, Vidyadharas, Gandharvas and Yakshas watched the great battle from above. Drona's bow was broken by a well-aimed shaft from Satyaki, and the son of Bharadwaja had to take another bow and, even as he strung it, Satyaki shot it down again. Drona took up another bow that too was shot down. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">And so it went on till Drona lost a hundred and one bows without being able to shoot an arrow. The great acharya said to himself: \"This man Satyaki is a warrior in the class of Sri Rama, Kartavirya, Dhananjaya and Bhishma,\"and was glad he had an opponent worthy of him. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">It was a craftsman's professional joy at skill displayed in the art he loved. For every specially-charged shaft that Drona sent, Satyaki had a ready answer of equivalent quality. Long did this equal combat continue. Drona of unrivalled skill in archery then resolved on killing Satyaki and sent the fire astra. But Satyaki saw this and, losing no time, sent the Varuna astra to counteract it.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">But now Satyaki's strength began to fail and, seeing this, the Kaurava warriors were glad and shouted in satisfaction. When Yudhishthira saw Satyaki was hard pressed, he told those nearby to go to Satyaki's relief. \"Our great and good hero Yuyudhana (Satyaki) is being overpowered by Drona. You should go there at once,\" he said to Dhrishtadyumna. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"The brahmana will otherwise slay Satyaki in a few minutes. Why are you hesitating? Go at once. Drona is playing with Satyaki as a cat plays with a bird. Satyaki is indeed in the paws of the Destroyer.\" Yudhishthira ordered the army to make a powerful attack on Drona. Satyaki was saved with difficulty. Just then, the sound of Krishna's conch was heard from the sector where Arjuna was fighting.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"O Satyaki, I hear Panchajanya,\" cried Yudhishthira; \"but the twang of Arjuna's bow does not accompany it. I fear Arjuna has been surrounded by Jayadratha's friends and is in danger. Arjuna is opposed by forces both in front of him and in<b> </b>his rear. He pierced the Kaurava ranks in the morning and he has not come back yet though the greater part of the day is gone. How is it that only Krishna's conch is heard? I fear Dhananjaya has been slain and therefore Krishna has taken up arms. Satyaki, there is nothing you cannot accomplish. Your bosom friend Arjuna, he, who taught you, is in mortal danger. Often has Arjuna spoken to me admiringly of your great skill and prowess. 'There is not another soldier like Satyaki,' he said to me when we were in the forest. Oh, look there! The dust is rising that side. I am certain Arjuna has been surrounded. Jayadratha is a powerful warrior, and there are many enemy warriors there helping him and resolved to die in defence of him. Go at once, Satyaki.\" Thus did Dharmaputra speak in great trepidation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Satyaki, who was weary after his battle with Drona, replied: \"Faultless among men, I shall obey your command. What would I not do for Dhananjaya's sake? My life is the merest trifle in my eyes. If you order me, I am ready to fight the gods themselves. But allow me to put before you what the wise Vasudeva and Arjuna told me when they left. 'Until we return after slaying Jayadratha you should not leave Yudhishthira's side. Be vigilant in protecting him. We entrust this to you in confidence and go. There is only one warrior in the Kaurava army whom we fear, and he is Drona. You know his sworn intention. We go leaving Dharmaputra's safety in our hands.' Thus said Vasudeva and Arjuna to me when they went. Arjuna laid this trust on me, believing me fit for it. How can I disregard his command? Do not have any fear about Arjuna's safety. No one can defeat him. The Sindhu king and the others cannot cope with a sixteenth part of Arjuna. Dharmaputra, to whom shall I entrust your safety if I must go? I see no one here who can stand against Drona if he comes to seize you. Do not ask me to go. Consider well before you command me to leave.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Satyaki,\" replied Yudhishthira, \"I have thought over it. As I have weighed the danger against the need and I have concluded that you must go. You leave me with my full permission. Here is the powerful Bhima to look to my safety. There is Dhrishtadyumna also, and there are many others besides. There is no need to worry about me.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoBodyTextIndent\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 1em 0in;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">So saying, Yudhishthira placed a boxful of arrows and other weapons in Satyaki's chariot and got fresh horses yoked thereto and sent Satyaki uttering benedictions on him. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Bhimasena, Yudhishthira is your charge. Be vigilant,\" said Satyaki, and went to join Dhananjaya.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Satyaki met with violent resistance as he proceeded to dash through the Kaurava forces. But he cut his way through bearing down all opposition. But the resistance was very stiff and his progress was slow. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When Drona saw Satyaki part from Yudhishthira, he began to assault the Pandava formation without rest or interval, until it began to break and retreat. Yudhishthira was greatly agitated.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; text-transform: uppercase;\">Yudhishthira's Fond Hope</span></b><span style=\"color: black;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"ARJUNA has not returned, nor has Satyaki, who was sent after him. Bhima, my fear grows. I hear the Panchajanya, but not the twang of Arjuna's bowstring. Satyaki, that bravest and most loyal of friends, has not come back with any tidings. My anxiety is increasing every moment,\" said Yudhishthira to Bhima in great perplexity of mind.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"I have never seen you so agitated,\" replied Bhimasena. \"Do, not let your fortitude grow less. Command me as you please. Do not let the wheels of your mind stick in the mud of anxiety.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Dearest Bhima, I fear your brother has been slain, and it seems to me Madhava has now himself taken up arms. I hear the conch of Madhava but I hear not the resounding twang of Gandiva. I fear Dhananjaya, the unrivalled hero, in whom were centerd all our hopes, has been killed. My mind is confused.<b> </b>If you would do as I tell you, go at once to where Arjuna is. Join him and Satyaki, and do what needs to be done, and come back.<b> </b>Satyaki, under orders from me, pierced the Kaurava ranks<b> </b>and proceeded in the direction of Arjuna. You go now, and do likewise and, if you indeed see them alive, I shall know it by your lion-roar.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"My Lord, do not grieve. I shall go and let you know they are safe,\" said Bhima, and immediately turning to Dhrishtadyumna said: \"Panchala, you know very well that Drona is seeking, by some means or other, to seize Dharmaputra alive. Our foremost duty is to protect the King. But I must also obey him and fulfil his command. And so I go, trusting him to your care.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Bhima, do not be concerned. Go with an assured mind. Drona cannot take Yudhishthira without first killing me,\" said the heroic son of Drupada, sworn enemy of Drona. And Bhima hurried away.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The Kauravas surrounded Bhima in full force and vowed to prevent him from going to Arjuna's relief. But like a lion scattering less noble beasts he put his enemies to flight, killing no less than eleven of the sons of Dhritarashtra. Bhima then approached Drona himself. \"Stop,\" cried Drona. \"Here I am, your enemy. You cannot proceed further without defeating me. Your brother Arjuna went in with my consent. But I cannot let you go.\" Drona spoke thus believing that he would receive the same courtesy from Bhima as he did from Arjuna. But Bhima was furious at hearing these words of Drona, and answered scornfully.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Oh brahmana, it was not with your permission that Arjuna went. He broke your resistance and pierced your battle lines fighting his way through, but he did not hurt you out of pity. But I shall not, like Arjuna, show mercy to you. I am your enemy. Once upon a time, you were our preceptor and were like a father to us. We respected you as such. Now, you have yourself said you are our enemy. May it be so!\" Saying this, Bhima aimed his mace at Drona's chariot that crumbled to pieces. And Drona had to take to another chariot. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The second chariot too was broken to pieces. And Bhima forced his way through overcoming all opposition. Drona lost eight chariots that day. And the army of the Bhojas, that tried to stop Bhima, was completely destroyed. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">He proceeded mowing down all opposition and reached where Arjuna was fighting Jayadratha's forces.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">As soon as he saw Arjuna, Bhima roared like a lion. Hearing that roar, Krishna and Arjuna were exceedingly pleased and raised yells of joy. Yudhishthira heard these roars and, relieved of his doubts and anxieties, he pronounced blessings on Arjuna. And he thought within himself: <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-SmhTlz4l4D0/TsM8p02yNFI/AAAAAAAAIrI/iVr7Fx4Bn4U/s1600/imagesCAXEGW3M.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-SmhTlz4l4D0/TsM8p02yNFI/AAAAAAAAIrI/iVr7Fx4Bn4U/s1600/imagesCAXEGW3M.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Before the sun sets today, Arjuna's oath will be fulfilled. He will slay the man who caused Abhimanyu's death and will return in triumph. Duryodhana may sue for peace after Jayadratha's death. Seeing so many of his brothers slain, it is possible that foolish Duryodhana may see light. The lives of numerous kings and great warriors have been sacrificed on the field of battle and even the stubborn and narrow-visioned Duryodhana may now see his fault and ask for peace. Will this indeed happen? The great grandsire Bhishma has been offered as a sacrifice. Will this wicked enmity end with it and shall we be saved from further cruel destruction?\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">While thus Yudhishthira was fondly hoping and dreaming of peace, the battle was raging with great fury where Bhima, Satyaki and Arjuna were engaging the enemy. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Only the Lord knows through what travail the world must evolve. His ways are inscrutable. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" class=\"MsoNormalTable\" style=\"mso-cellspacing: 1.5pt; mso-yfti-tbllook: 1184; width: 100%;\"><tbody>\n<tr style=\"mso-yfti-firstrow: yes; mso-yfti-irow: 0;\">   <td style=\"background-color: transparent; border: rgb(0, 0, 0); padding: 0.75pt;\"><div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%; text-transform: uppercase;\">Karna And Bhima</span></b><span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">ARJUNA had left Yudhishthira behind to repel Drona's attacks and   had gone to make good his word that before sunset Jayadratha would lie dead   on the field of battle. </span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-SB2i31vo19s/TsM8lF97hcI/AAAAAAAAIrA/7GabbjB4WWU/s1600/imagesCAVZ7PAQ.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-SB2i31vo19s/TsM8lF97hcI/AAAAAAAAIrA/7GabbjB4WWU/s1600/imagesCAVZ7PAQ.jpg\" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Jayadratha had been the main cause of Abhimanyu's death. He it   was who had effectively prevented the relief of Abhimanyu by the Pandavas,   and thereby caused Abhimanyu to be isolated, overpowered and slain.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">We have seen how Yudhishthira in his anxiety sent first Satyaki   and then Bhima to join Arjuna in his battle against Jayadratha. Bhima reached   where Arjuna was engaged and sounded his simhanada (lion-roar). Dharmaputra   heard the lion-roar of Bhima and knew that Arjuna was found alive.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It was the fourteenth day and the battle raged fiercely at many   points, between Satyaki and Bhurisravas at one place, between Bhima and Karna   at another and between Arjuna and Jayadratha at a third. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Drona remained at the main front resisting the attack of the   Panchalas and the Pandavas, and leading a counter-offensive against them.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Duryodhana arrived with his forces at the sector where Arjuna   attacked Jayadratha, but was soon defeated and turned back. The battle thus   raged long and furiously on more than one front. The armies were so deployed   that each side was exposed to danger in its rear. </span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-dUMoOuWOU34/TsM8gtDM_xI/AAAAAAAAIq4/wY0aE870H1Q/s1600/imagesCAV3K7OM.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-dUMoOuWOU34/TsM8gtDM_xI/AAAAAAAAIq4/wY0aE870H1Q/s1600/imagesCAV3K7OM.jpg\" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Duryodhana was speaking to Drona: <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Arjuna, Bhima and Satyaki have treated us with contempt   and proceeded successfully to Jayadratha's sector and they are pressing hard   on the Sindhu king. It is indeed strange that, under your command, our battle   array should have been broken and our plans completely foiled. Everyone asks   how it is that the great Drona with all his mastery of the science of war has   been so badly outmaneuvered. What answer shall I make? I have been betrayed   by you.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Duryodhana thus, once again, bitterly reproached Drona, who   replied unperturbed:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Duryodhana, your accusations are as unworthy as they are   contrary to truth. There is nothing to be gained by talking about what is   past and beyond repair. Think of what is to be done now.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Sir, it is for you to advise me. Tell me what should be   done. Give your best consideration to the difficulties of the situation and   decide and let us do it quickly.\" Puzzled and perplexed, thus did   Duryodhana plead.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Drona replied: \"My son, the situation is no doubt serious.   Three great generals have advanced, outmanoeuvring us. But they have as much   reason to be anxious as we, for their rear is now left as open to attack as   ours. We are on both sides of them and their position is not therefore safe.   Be heartened, go up to Jayadratha again, and do all you can to support him.   It is of no avail to dishearten oneself by dwelling on past defeats and   difficulties. It is best I stay here and send you reinforcements as and when   required. I must keep the Panchalas and Pandava army engaged here. Otherwise,   we shall be wholly destroyed.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Accordingly, Duryodhana went with fresh reinforcements again to   where Arjuna was directing his attack on Jayadratha. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The narrative of the fourteenth day's fighting at Kurukshetra   shows that, even in the Mahabharata times, the modern tactics of turning and   enveloping movements was not unknown.</span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-zGQn7mGSrL4/TsM8aCe3lRI/AAAAAAAAIqw/Y_kkm7af2rs/s1600/imagesCAUW8544.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-zGQn7mGSrL4/TsM8aCe3lRI/AAAAAAAAIqw/Y_kkm7af2rs/s1600/imagesCAUW8544.jpg\" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The advantages and risks of such strategy appear to have been   fully understood and discussed even in those days. Arjuna's flanking   manoeuvres perplexed his enemies greatly. The story of that day's battle   between Bhima and Karna reads very much like a chapter from the narrative of   a modern war. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhima did not desire to fight Karna or remain long engaged with   him. He was eager to reach where Arjuna was. But Radheya would, by no means,   permit him to do this. He showered his arrows on Bhimasena and stopped him   from proceeding. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The contrast between the two warriors was striking. Karna's   handsome lotus-like face was radiant with smiles when he attacked Bhima   saying: \"Do not show your back,\" \"Now, do not flee like a   coward,\" and so on. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhima was all anger when taunted in this manner. He was maddened   by Karna's smiles. The battle was fierce but Karna did everything with a   smiling air of ease whereas Bhima's face glowed with rage and his movements   were violent. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Karna would keep at a distance and send his well-aimed shafts   but Bhima would disregard the arrows and javelins failing thick upon him and   always try to close with Karna. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Radheya did everything he did, calmly and with graceful ease,   whereas Bhimasena fumed and fretted with impatience, as he showed his amazing   strength of limb. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhima was red with bleeding wounds all over and presented the   appearance of an Asoka tree in full blossom. But he minded them not, as he   attacked Karna cutting bows in twain and smashing his chariot. </span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-TH1QZQry6ps/TsM8NzFDxKI/AAAAAAAAIqg/dJdqOYaYq6Y/s1600/imagesCAUQCALE.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-TH1QZQry6ps/TsM8NzFDxKI/AAAAAAAAIqg/dJdqOYaYq6Y/s1600/imagesCAUQCALE.jpg\" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When Karna had to run for a fresh chariot, there was no smile on   his face. For anger rose in him, like the sea on a full moon day, as he   attacked Bhima. Both showed the strength of tigers and the speed of eagles   and their anger was now like that of serpents in a fury. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhima brought before his mind all the insults and injuries which   he and his brothers and Draupadi had suffered, and fought desperately, caring   not for life. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The two cars dashed against each other and the milk white horses   of Karna's chariot and Bhimasena's black horses jostled in the combat like   clouds in a thunderstorm. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Karna's bow was shattered and his charioteer reeled and fell.   Karna then hurled a javelin at Bhima. But Bhima parried it and continued   pouring his arrows on Karna, who had taken up a fresh bow.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again and again did Karna lose his chariot. Duryodhana saw   Karna's plight and calling his brother Durjaya said: \"This wicked   Pandava will kill Karna. Go at once and attack Bhima and save Karna's   life.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Durjaya went as ordered<b> </b>and attacked Bhima who, in a rage   sent seven shafts which sent Durjaya's horses and his charioteer to the abode   of Yama and Durjaya himself fell mortally wounded. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Seeing his bleeding body wriggling on the ground like a wounded   snake, Karna was overwhelmed with grief and circled round the hero, paying   mournful honor to the dead.</span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Kx6UfYNFcyw/TsM8I_e8a8I/AAAAAAAAIqY/krPjnmoSIYE/s1600/imagesCAUD070M.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Kx6UfYNFcyw/TsM8I_e8a8I/AAAAAAAAIqY/krPjnmoSIYE/s1600/imagesCAUD070M.jpg\" /></a></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhima did not stop but continued the fight and greatly harassed   Karna. Karna once again had to find a fresh chariot. He sent well aimed   shafts and hit Bhima who in a fury hurled his mace at Karna and it crashed on   Karna's chariot and killed his charioteer and horses and broke the flagstaff.   Karna now stood on the ground with bent bow. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Duryodhana now sent another brother to relieve Karna. Durmukha   went accordingly and took Karna on his chariot. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Seeing yet another son of Dhritarashtra come to offer himself up   to death, Bhima licked his lips in gusto and sent nine shafts on the newly   arrived enemy. And, even as Karna climbed up to take his seat in the chariot,   Durmukha's armor was broken and he fell lifeless.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When Karna saw the warrior bathed in blood and lying dead by his   side, he was again overwhelmed with grief and stood motionless for a while. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bhima relentlessly continued his attack on Karna. His sharp   arrows pierced Karna's coat of armor and he was in pain. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">But he too at once returned the attack and wounded Bhima all   over. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Still the Pandava would not stop and attacked Karna furiously.   The sight of so many of Duryodhana's brothers dying for his sake one after   another was too much for Karna.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 0in 0in 10pt; mso-margin-bottom-alt: auto; mso-margin-top-alt: auto;\">\n<span style=\"color: black; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">This, and the physical pain of his own wounds made him lose   courage and he turned away defeated. But, when Bhima stood up on the field of   battle red with wounds all over like a flaming fire and emitted a triumphant   yell, he could not brook it but returned to the combat.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</td>  </tr>\n<tr style=\"mso-yfti-irow: 1; mso-yfti-lastrow: yes;\">   <td style=\"background-color: transparent; border: rgb(0, 0, 0); padding: 0.75pt;\"><div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-OsIuqVfRZKE/TsJleI_FWzI/AAAAAAAAIhg/6JcBVKbX8Yo/s1600/imagesCAY5XFT1.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-OsIuqVfRZKE/TsJleI_FWzI/AAAAAAAAIhg/6JcBVKbX8Yo/s1600/imagesCAY5XFT1.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<div align=\"center\">\n<table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" class=\"MsoNormalTable\" style=\"mso-cellspacing: 0in; mso-padding-alt: 0in 0in 0in 0in; mso-yfti-tbllook: 1184; width: 100%;\"><tbody>\n<tr style=\"mso-yfti-firstrow: yes; mso-yfti-irow: 0; mso-yfti-lastrow: yes;\">     <td style=\"background-color: transparent; border: rgb(0, 0, 0); padding: 0in; width: 100%;\" width=\"100%\"></td>    </tr>\n</tbody></table>\n</div>\n</td>  </tr>\n</tbody></table>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; text-transform: uppercase;\">Pledge Respected</span></b><span style=\"color: black;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">DHRITARASHTRA, hearing of the slaughter of his sons and the check received by Karna, was desolate. \"O Sanjaya, like moths falling in<b> </b>the fire, my sons are being destroyed. The stubborn Duryodhana has led the lads Durmukha and Durjaya, to their doom. Alas, I have lost these boys! The fool said: 'Karna, unrivalled among men for courage and the accomplishment of war, is on our side. Who then can defeat us? Even the gods cannot win a battle against me when Karna is on my side. What can these Pandavas do to me?' But now he has seen Karna beating a retreat when Bhimasena attacked him. Has he seen wisdom at least now? Alas, Sanjaya, my son has earned the undying hatred of the son of Vayu, Bhima, who has the strength of the god of death! We are indeed ruined!\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Sanjaya replied: \"O king, was it not you who brought about this unquenchable hatred, listening to the words of your foolish and stubborn son? To you indeed must be traced this greater disaster. You are now but reaping the fruit of your discarding the advice of Bhishma and the other elders. Blame yourself, king. Do not blame Karna and the brave warriors who have done their best in battle.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-FyNMOC0XrDc/TsJli9U49tI/AAAAAAAAIho/tKRdgwYq4j0/s1600/imagesCAY7WV9M.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-FyNMOC0XrDc/TsJli9U49tI/AAAAAAAAIho/tKRdgwYq4j0/s1600/imagesCAY7WV9M.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoBodyTextIndent\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 1em 0in;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">After thus admonishing the blind king, Sanjaya proceeded to tell him what happened. Five sons of Dhritarashtra, Durmarsha, Dussaha, Durmata, Durdhara and Jaya, when they saw Karna put to flight by Bhima at once rushed on the latter. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When Karna saw this, he was heartened and turned back to resume his attack. Bhimasena at first ignored the sons of Dhritarashtra and concentrated on Karna. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-iNVs6LDSVmw/TsM8DSJIWXI/AAAAAAAAIqQ/aypXLvDDV5s/s1600/imagesCAU4NLDH.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-iNVs6LDSVmw/TsM8DSJIWXI/AAAAAAAAIqQ/aypXLvDDV5s/s1600/imagesCAU4NLDH.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoBodyTextIndent\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 1em 0in;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">But they became so violent in their assault that Bhima got incensed and, turning his attentions on them, disposed of all five of them. They lay dead on the field, with their horses and their charioteers. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The young warriors with their bleeding wounds presented the appearance of a forest with trees, uprooted by a strong wind and lying flat on the ground with their beautiful red blossoms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When Karna saw another batch of princes slaughtered for his sake he fought more grimly than ever before. Bhima too was more violent than before, thinking of all the evil that Karna had wrought against the Pandavas. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">He used his bow so as to disarm Karna completely. His horses and charioteer were also laid low. Karna now jumped down from his chariot and hurled his mace at Bhima. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">But Bhima warded it off with shafts from his powerful bow and covered Karna with a shower of arrows and forced him to turn back and walk on foot.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-qKdoJdt4kJc/TsJlni4OiPI/AAAAAAAAIhw/KCnSOdmDoBY/s1600/imagesCAYA8NKD.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-qKdoJdt4kJc/TsJlni4OiPI/AAAAAAAAIhw/KCnSOdmDoBY/s1600/imagesCAYA8NKD.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana, who watched this combat, was greatly grieved and sent seven of his brothers Chitra, Upachitra, Chitraksha, Charuchitra, Sarasana, Chitrayudha and Chitravarman, to relieve Radheya. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">They gave battle to Bhima displaying great skill and energy. But fell dead one after another, for Bhima's passion was roused and his attack was irresistible. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When Karna saw so many of the sons of Dhritarashtra sacrificing themselves for him, his face was wet with tears and he mounted a fresh chariot and began to attack Bhima with deadly effect. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-9aJQ6hrVGaQ/TsM7_M_OGiI/AAAAAAAAIqI/XnIsg2_swsI/s1600/imagesCATJT4HZ.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-9aJQ6hrVGaQ/TsM7_M_OGiI/AAAAAAAAIqI/XnIsg2_swsI/s1600/imagesCATJT4HZ.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The two combatants clashed like clouds in a thunderstorm. Kesava, Satyaki and Arjuna were filled with admiration and joy as they watched Bhima fighting. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhurisravas, Kripacharya, Aswatthama, Salya, Jayadratha and many other warriors of the Kaurava army also broke into exclamations, astonished at the way in which Bhima fought. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Duryodhana was stung to the quick and burned with anger. Karna's plight caused him extreme anxiety. He feared Bhima would kill Radheya that day, and sent seven more of his brothers directing them to surround Bhima and attack him simultaneously.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The seven brothers sent by Duryodhana attacked Bhima. But fell one after another, struck down by his arrows. Vikarna, who was killed last, was beloved of all. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When Bhima saw him fall dead after a brave fight, he was deeply moved and exclaimed: \"Alas, O Vikarna, you were just and knew what was dharma! You fought in loyal obedience to the call of duty. I had to kill even you. Indeed this battle is a curse upon us wherein men like you and the grandsire Bhishma have had to be slaughtered.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Seeing Duryodhana's brothers, who came to help him, slain one after another in this manner, Karna was overwhelmed by anguish. He leant back on his seat in the chariot and closed his eyes unable to bear the sight. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-QvyTPhdaGmk/TsJlsBJcEoI/AAAAAAAAIh4/RxvfH76bPoc/s1600/imagesCAYD1LFA.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-QvyTPhdaGmk/TsJlsBJcEoI/AAAAAAAAIh4/RxvfH76bPoc/s1600/imagesCAYD1LFA.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Then recovering control over his emotions he hardened his heart and began again his attack on Bhima. Bow after bow was broken up by Bhimasena's shaft, but Karna kept the battle. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Eighteen times he had to take up a fresh bow. Karna had long ago discarded his smile and his face showed savage anger even as Bhima's. They now glared fiercely at each other as they fought. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Yudhishthira now heard Bhima's roar rise above the tumult of battle, and heartened by it, he fought Drona with increased vigor. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-tH3VLRAI56k/TsM75Tl35HI/AAAAAAAAIqA/8cfEEj6HSv4/s1600/imagesCAR44J5U.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-tH3VLRAI56k/TsM75Tl35HI/AAAAAAAAIqA/8cfEEj6HSv4/s1600/imagesCAR44J5U.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">In the renewed and fierce battle between Bhima and Karna, Bhima lost his horses and charioteer. Soon his chariot also was smashed to pieces. Then, Bhima hurled his spear at Karna who was in his chariot and as Karna parried it with his shaft, Bhima advanced with sword and shield. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">But Karna broke the shield at once with his shafts. Then, Bhima whirled his sword and hurled it, and it cut Karna's bow into two and fell on the ground. But Karna took up yet another bow and assailed Bhima with arrows more fiercely than before. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhima, in a fit of uncontrollable rage, sprang upon Karna. Radheya took cover behind his flagstaff and escaped destruction. Thereupon, Bhima jumped out of Karna's car down into the field of battle where, deprived of all arms, he used the elephants lying dead on the ground to protect himself from Karna's arrows and continued the fight. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-3P616OJxj1A/TsJlxaeJYZI/AAAAAAAAIiA/ZypNjbnPhN8/s1600/SS.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-3P616OJxj1A/TsJlxaeJYZI/AAAAAAAAIiA/ZypNjbnPhN8/s1600/SS.png\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">He picked up anything he could lay hands upon, wheels of broken chariots, the limbs of horses and elephants that were lying about, and hurling them at Karna, kept him engaged without interval. But this could not long continue and Bhima was soon at a great disadvantage. Karna said exultingly: <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Foolish glutton, you do not know the science of war; why do you engage yourself in battle here? Go to the jungle and fill yourself with fruits and roots and grow fat. You are a savage, not fit for kshatriya battle. Get away!\" Hurling insulting taunts at him, he made the helpless Bhima burn with rage, but mindful of his word to Kunti, refrained from killing him. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"There, Arjuna! See how poor Bhima is being harassed by Karna,\" said Krishna. Dhananjaya's eyes burned red with wrath, when he saw the plight of his valiant brother.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">He bent his Gandiva bow and discharged his arrows on Karna who then gladly turned his attentions from Bhima to Arjuna. He had pledged his word to Kunti not to kill more than one of the Pandavas and he reserved that option for the great Arjuna. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-tu7RTwh0Knw/TsM70s_W7zI/AAAAAAAAIp4/-NVMf3LyS2M/s1600/imagesCAR8QVKV.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-tu7RTwh0Knw/TsM70s_W7zI/AAAAAAAAIp4/-NVMf3LyS2M/s1600/imagesCAR8QVKV.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<b><span style=\"color: black; text-transform: uppercase;\">Somadatta's End</span></b><span style=\"color: black;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"THERE comes the valorous Satyaki,\" said Krishna, the charioteer, to Dhananjaya. \"Your disciple and friend is marching up, triumphantly breaking through enemy ranks.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"I do not like it, Madhava,\" replied Arjuna. \"It was not right for him to have left Dharmaputra and come here to join me. Drona is there ever seeking an opportunity to seize Dharmaputra. Satyaki should have stuck to his post there to guard him. Instead, he has come here. Old Bhurisravas has intercepted Satyaki. It was a great mistake for Yudhishthira to have sent Satyaki away here.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">There was a family feud between Bhurisravas and Satyaki that made them inveterate foes. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoBodyTextIndent\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 1em 0in;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">It had come about this way. When Devaki, who was to be the blessed mother of Sri Krishna, was a maiden, many princes competed for her hand and there was a great battle between Somadatta and Sini over it.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-_ziDTQffFt0/TsJl3aWYRCI/AAAAAAAAIiI/oEHoXY7BMGA/s1600/untitled.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-_ziDTQffFt0/TsJl3aWYRCI/AAAAAAAAIiI/oEHoXY7BMGA/s1600/untitled.png\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Sini won, and on behalf of Vasudeva he placed Devaki in his chariot and took her away. Since that incident there was feud between the two clans, the Sini family and that of Somadatta. Satyaki was Sini's grandson. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-4F4ksVjTvLk/TsM7wky5LmI/AAAAAAAAIpw/eSq10WMqRfw/s1600/imagesCAR3QMU3.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-4F4ksVjTvLk/TsM7wky5LmI/AAAAAAAAIpw/eSq10WMqRfw/s1600/imagesCAR3QMU3.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhurisravas was Somadatta's son. When they found themselves on opposite sides in the Kurukshetra battle, it was natural that, as soon as Bhurisravas saw Satyaki, the old warrior challenged Satyaki to battle. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Oh Satyaki,\" cried Bhurisravas, \"I know you strut about thinking yourself a man of great prowess. Here now I have you in my power and will presently finish you. Long have I sought for this meeting. Like Indrajit destroyed Dasaratha's son Lakshmana, you will die today and go to the abode of Yama, gladdening the hearts of many a bereaved widow.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Satyaki laughed. \"Have done with your vaunting,\" he interrupted. \"Words are not deeds and do not frighten fighting men. Demonstrate your valor in action and do not indulge in dry thunder like autumn clouds.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">After this exchange of words, the battle began, and the combat was as between two fierce lions. Their horses were killed, their bows were broken, and both were rendered chariotless. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-OybxR3SIByQ/TsM7spI5oKI/AAAAAAAAIpo/Duzf4VZ2Djs/s1600/imagesCAQWLZPZ.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-OybxR3SIByQ/TsM7spI5oKI/AAAAAAAAIpo/Duzf4VZ2Djs/s1600/imagesCAQWLZPZ.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">They were now standing on the ground fighting with swords and shields, till their shields were hacked to bits and their swords broken. Then they were locked in a deadly embrace without weapons. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">They rolled together on the ground. They leaped up and they sprang on each other. They fell down again and so the combat went on for a long while.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Partha's mind was at the time concentrated on Jayadratha's movements and he did not watch this combat between Satyaki and the son of Somadatta. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">But his charioteer Krishna was deeply concerned about Satyaki's fate. For Krishna knew about their family feud.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-sZ6ryuBPfJQ/TsJl7hW8Z4I/AAAAAAAAIiQ/G62357o7jYs/s1600/C.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-sZ6ryuBPfJQ/TsJl7hW8Z4I/AAAAAAAAIiQ/G62357o7jYs/s1600/C.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoBodyTextIndent\" style=\"line-height: 150%; margin: 1em 0in;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Dhananjaya,\" said Krishna, \"Satyaki is exhausted. Bhurisravas is going to kill him now.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Still Arjuna was following only Jayadratha's movements. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Satyaki who came after an exhausting battle with the Kaurava forces has been forced to accept Bhurisravas' challenge,\" said Krishna again. \"It is a most unequal battle. Unless we help him, beloved Yuyudhana will be slain.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Even as Krishna was saying this, Bhurisravas lifted Satyaki up and brought him crashing to the ground and all the men around in the Kaurava army exclaimed: \"Yuyudhana is dead!\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-ApVcNkIa0OY/TsM6UduRDZI/AAAAAAAAIn4/LmCmfINUgfs/s1600/imagesCAG9RBY6.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-ApVcNkIa0OY/TsM6UduRDZI/AAAAAAAAIn4/LmCmfINUgfs/s1600/imagesCAG9RBY6.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Again Krishna importuned: \"Satyaki is lying almost dead on the field, the best among the Vrishni clan. One who came to help you, is being killed before your eyes. You are looking on, doing nothing.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhurisravas caught hold of the prostrate Satyaki and dragged him on the ground as a lion drags its elephant prey.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Q2jc5GFpsPY/TsM7nxE07YI/AAAAAAAAIpg/yDuYWx_OWMs/s1600/imagesCAQ9CI2E.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Q2jc5GFpsPY/TsM7nxE07YI/AAAAAAAAIpg/yDuYWx_OWMs/s1600/imagesCAQ9CI2E.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna was in a great conflict of mind. \"Bhurisravas has not been called to battle by me, nor has he challenged me to fight. How can I send my shaft at Bhurisravas when he is engaged with another? My mind recoils from such an act, although it is true a friend who came to help me is being slaughtered before my eyes.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Just as Arjuna finished saying this to Krishna, the sky was darkened by a cloud of arrows sent by Jayadratha. Arjuna replied with a shower of arrows, but he constantly turned with pain to where Satyaki was in the mortal grip of Bhurisravas.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Krishna again pressed Arjuna to consider Satyaki's condition. \"O Partha, Satyaki has lost all his weapons and he is now in Bhurisravas' power, helpless.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">When Arjuna turned, he saw Bhurisravas with his foot on the prostrate body of Satyaki and sword upraised to slay him. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Before Bhurisravas could deliver the fatal thrust, Arjuna shot an arrow which went with the speed of lightning and the next moment the uplifted arm fell chopped off to the ground still holding the sword. Bhurisravas, all amazed, turned and saw who had done it.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-vARwvyhhFvA/TsM7jU_nAYI/AAAAAAAAIpY/pJSp-q9LP1c/s1600/imagesCAPUE0UU.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-vARwvyhhFvA/TsM7jU_nAYI/AAAAAAAAIpY/pJSp-q9LP1c/s1600/imagesCAPUE0UU.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">\"Son of Kunti,\" he exclaimed, \"I had not expected this of you! It befits not a warrior to shoot from behind in this manner. I was engaged in combat with someone else and you have attacked me without notice. Indeed, then, no man can resist the evil influence of the company he keeps, as your unchivalrous conduct proves. Dhananjaya, when you go back to your brother Dharmaputra, what account are you going to give him of this valorous deed. Ah! Who taught you this low trick, Arjuna? Did you learn this from your father Indra or from your teachers Drona and Kripa? What code of conduct was it that permitted you to shoot your arrow at a man who was engaged in combat with another and could not so much as turn his eyes on you? You have done the deed of a low-bred fellow and foully besmirched your honor. You must have been instigated into it by the son of Vasudeva. It was not in your own nature to do it. No one with princely blood in his veins would think of such a dastardly deed. I know you have been incited to it by that contemptible Krishna.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Thus did Bhurisravas with his right arm cut off, bitterly denounce Krishna and Arjuna in the Kurukshetra field.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Said Partha: \"Bhurisravas, you are old and age seems to have affected your judgment. You accuse Hrishikesa and me without cause. How could I look on doing nothing, when, before my eyes, you were in the act of killing my friend, who came and risked his life in battle on my behalf, one who was like a right hand to me, and whom you were going to stab when he was lying helpless on the ground? I would have deserved to go to hell if I had failed to intervene. You say, I have been ruined by keeping company with Madhava. Who in the wide world would not wish to be so ruined? You have spoken out of confused understanding. Satyaki who was weary and exhausted when he came here and who was inadequately armed, was challenged by you to give battle. You overcame him. Having been defeated, he lay on the ground, powerless. What code of honor enabled you to raise your sword to thrust it into the body of the fallen warrior and slay him? Do I not remember how you cheered the man who killed my boy Abhimanyu when he stood staggering, exhausted and weaponless, his coat of armor torn off?\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhurisravas who heard this did not answer but spread his arrows on the ground with his left hand and made a seat for meditation. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The old warrior sat in yoga and the sight deeply moved all the Kaurava soldiers. They cheered Bhurisravas and uttered reproaches against Krishna and Arjuna.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Arjuna spoke: \"Brave men, I am sworn to protect every friend within bow-shot of me and I cannot let an enemy kill him. It is my sacred pledge. Why do you blame me? It is not right to hurl reproaches without due thought.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">After saying this to the warriors in the field who reproached him, he turned to Bhurisravas and said: \"O excellent among brave men, you have protected many who have gone to you for help. You know that what has happened is due to your own error. There is no justice in blaming me. If you like, let us all blame the violence which governs kshatriya life.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Bhurisravas, who heard this, lowered his head in salutation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-z4Sx5BsQ6CQ/TsJmGZPteMI/AAAAAAAAIiY/hGR8FetcSOo/s1600/imagesCAOSWZA7.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-z4Sx5BsQ6CQ/TsJmGZPteMI/AAAAAAAAIiY/hGR8FetcSOo/s1600/imagesCAOSWZA7.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Satyaki now recovered consciousness and rose. Carried away by the impetuosity of his passion, he picked up a sword and, advancing to Bhurisravas, sitting in yoga on his seat of arrows, even when all around were shouting in horror and before Krishna and Arjuna, who rushed to the spot, could prevent him, with one swift and powerful cut, he struck off the old warrior's head which rolled down, while the body was still in the posture of meditation. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">The gods and the siddhas, who looked on from above the battlefield, uttered blessings on Bhurisravas. Everyone in the field condemned Satyaki's act.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"color: black;\">Satyaki maintained he was right, saying: \"After I fell down senseless, this enemy of my family placed his foot on my prostrate figure and attempted to kill me.
